content.description: Another really cool boulder problem. A couple slopey finger dishes with crimps and a crystal or two going up this slab. I enjoyed this problem a lot! Very relaxing.
content.location:
This is just to the right of "

5.7+ Crack Problem

." Also see details of "

5.7+ Crack Problem

" of where the boulder is located. But I started this standing where as a sit start might go as a V3? I'm not sure. (See picture for visual.)

content.description: The sharp arête on the front of the main rock formation at the bunker. Start off the ground for full value VS starting off the block behind the route. Climbs a very bouldery and wind polished arête up arguably some of the best moves on any sport climb at Vedauwoo.
content.protection:
3 bolts and an optional nut where the top connects with

Spirits Rebellious

.

content.description:
This is a goofy little problem that is actually way better than it looks.   It is very short, just a couple of moves, and it doesn't look too difficult.

But there is actually pretty tricky sloper pulling and the feet are down right small.   The finish for me is a sort of a beached whale flop onto the top of the thing.  Hilarious.
content.protection: Just don't hit your face on the rock if your feet pop - pad and spotter are nice as always, but not necessary.
content.location: The bunker breaks into several different areas.  The main area is the big pile of rocks that includes the sport routes mentioned on this site.    There is a smaller area that the Bagdonas book calls "Bunker B", which is a couple 100 feet east of the main area.  Trojan is in the middle of this part of the bunker, it is pretty easy to spot if you walk around and reference the photo.

content.description:
The left arching flared crack starting on the right side of the face and finishing at arete finish of

Tugging Softly

.
content.protection:
Natural protection to shared Fixe rings above

Tugging Softly

.

content.description:
Rodeo Clown has sweet, techy face climbing while protecting in horizontals. way off the beaten path.

Original line: start off the pedestal on the middle of the face, just to the right of the black water streak. Climb up and slightly left until about mid-height, step left, and then go up and slightly left until the last bulge where you step right. If this sounds confusing, just follow the past of least resistance. Any other line up would be beyond 5.11.

Variation: naively thinking this was a new route, I started from the left side of the wall, climbed up and right until I encountered a sweet cobble mantel. After on top of the cobble, you have joined the original route.

Either way you do it, it's 5.11 face.
content.protection:
Mainly small stuff, all placed in the obvious horizontals. The horizontal cracks were a bit dirty, so bring a nut tool.

You can get a gear anchor up top. You can easily walk around to the large ledge and toprope the climb. If you do this, bring some material to extend the anchor approximately 15 feet or so.
content.location: This climb is located on the large, low angle, and broken dome just past the main Bunker area. Once you hit the Bunker, drive around it to left, and follow the road until it dead ends up on a big flat rocky area with a campfire. Walk straight toward the dome, staying at the same elevation as the parking. Tucked in a grassy alcove, you will find the wall. It sits below most of the other formations on the dome. It is on the West side of the formation and faces Northwest. It takes approximately a 5 minute approach from the parking.

climbs.name: Hugs and Kisses from Salt Lake City

content.description: The large pillar on the north side of the bunker formation, start on the right corner and climb up and establish yourself on the pillar, alternating use of the right and left aretes.
content.protection: 2 bolts to Fixe rings (stick cliping first is a good idea).

content.description:
A great problem with a testy crux down low.  Then jugs on a fairly tall wall to top out.

Start on underclings, to a wicked crimp, to a dynamic throw to a jug.  This whole sequence is the crux, and is right near the ground.  If you tag the incut jug, it is just a tall cruise to the top.
content.location: The bunker splits into several different areas.  The  main area  is in the big rocks with the sport climbs that are mentioned on this site.  Asha is in a site a couple hundred feet to the east, called "Bunker B" in the Bagdonas book.   Easy to spot with the attached photo.

content.description: A beautiful crack problem that runs up a nicely-sized boulder. Great for beginners looking to get into "highballs", I suppose. Rock quality is good.
content.location:
It is located on the first boulder you drive by when you first pull into the Bunker area. It's a fairly identifiable boulder problem. It is south-facing crack.

Sit start on obvious holds and move into the crack (see picture and video in the comment area).
